Let $f(m,n)$ be maximal such that any graph on $n$ vertices in which every induced subgraph on $m$ vertices has an independent set of size at least $\log n$ must contain an independent set of size at least $f(n)$.

Estimate $f(n)$. In particular, is it true that $f((\log n)^2,n) \geq n^{1/2-o(1)}$? Is it true that $f((\log n)^3,n)\gg (\log n)^3$?



A question of Erd\H{o}s and Hajnal. Alon and Sudakov \cite{AlSu07} proved that in fact\[\frac{(\log n)^2}{\log\log n}\ll f((\log n)^2,n) \ll (\log n)^2\]and\[f((\log n)^3,n)\asymp \frac{(\log n)^2}{\log\log n}.\]See also [805].




References


[AlSu07] Alon, Noga and Sudakov, Benny, On graphs with subgraphs having large independence numbers. J. Graph Theory (2007), 149-157.
